secondaryIdInfos.domain: Bucheon St Marys' Hospital, The Catholic University of Korea

identificationModule.briefTitle: Pilot Study of Efficacy of Mechanical Insufflation Exsufflation in Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Effects of Mechanical Insufflation-exsufflation in Stroke Patients With Dysphagia - Pilot Study

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Stroke patients with dysphagia have restrictive lung dysfunction and impaired cough response. This pilot study was performed to determine if Mechanical Insufflation Exsufflation (MIE) therapy can help recover impaired cough function.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
Mechanical Insufflation- Exsufflation (MI-E) is an assisted coughing machine that has been proven to be very effective in preventing the deterioration of pulmonary function in patients with degenerative neuromuscular disorders. Impaired airway clearance in stroke patients is associated with increased incidence of aspiration pneumonia.

In this pilot study the investigators attempt to assess the efficacy of MI-E as part of a protocol for patients with dysphagia with impaired cough response.

keywords: stroke, dysphagia, cough, mechanical insufflation exsufflation

armGroups.label: Mechanical insufflation exsufflation
armGroups.description: Application of cough assist machine as part of the regular physiotherapy

interventions.name: Mechanical Insufflation Exsufflation
interventions.description: Mechanical Insufflation Exsufflation -Each patient received daily treatments by means of a light-weight, elastic oronasal mask. Treatments were divided between morning and afternoon and were carried out 5 times a week. A total of 20 sessions were carried out by a a trained respiratory therapist.

primaryOutcomes.measure: Coughing force as assessed by peak cough flow meter

secondaryOutcomes.measure: Cough force during reflexive cough test

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion criteria Presence of neurogenic dysphagia Presence of impaired cough function

Exclusion criteria Episodes of acute pneumonia or diagnosis of pulmonary embolism at time of enrollment.

Previous history of chronic respiratory dysfunction or other systemic disorders that may impair respiratory function (ex,rheumatoid arthritis, chronic renal disorder, spinal cord injury) Episodes of diaphragm weakness due to peripheral polyneuropathy or phrenic nerve injury Concomitant diagnosis of myopathy, muscular dystrophy, or other neurodegenerative disorders.

Episodes of rib fracture within one year of enrollment. Chronic alcoholism Diagnosis of bullous emphysema Diagnosis of chronic renal failure
